titleStmt.title: A brief and compendiouse table, in a maner of a concordaunce openyng the waye to the principall histories of the whole Bible, and the moste co[m]mon articles grounded and comprehended in the newe Testament and olde, in maner as amply as doeth the great concordau[n]ce of the Bible. Gathered and set furth by Henry Bollynger, Leo Iude, Conrade Pellicane, and by the other ministers of the church of Tygurie. And nowe first imprinted in Englyshe. D.M.L. [sic] The third boke of the Machabees a booke of the Bible also prynted vnto this boke which was neuer before translated or prynted in any Englyshe Bible. The contents of this booke are conteyned in the next leafe.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the right noble and vertuouÅ¿e Lady. Lady Anne, doucheÅ¿Å¿e of SomerÅ¿et &c, her moÅ¿te bounden and dayly Oratour Gwalter Lynne wyÅ¿hed aboundaunce of all grace and Godlynes wyth a longe and proÅ¿perous eÅ¿tate, to Goddis honour and your graces health and Å¿aluacyon.
div.p:
BEinge credibly enformed (mooÅ¿te graciouÅ¿e Lady) by Å¿uch as be nygh about your grace, that youre graces chiefe and daylye Å¿tudy is in the holy Byble: I thought I coulde not preÅ¿ente your grace wyth any Iuwell more acceptable and pleaÅ¿aunt to your grace then Å¿uche a bryefe concordaunce. Whereby youre grace myghte wyth more redynes fynde all Å¿uche thynges, as you Å¿houlde be deÅ¿yrouÅ¿e
to Å¿ee.
â¢ ctuum â¢â¦ .a.Then as for gold or Å¿iluer I am not able to preÅ¿ente vnto your grace but my ruyde laboures and that I do wyth all my herte. When thys lyttle boke therfore came to my hand (beynge wrytten in the hygh Almayne tounge) and I perceiued it to be mooÅ¿t diligently gathered out of the holy Byble and Å¿et in Å¿uche order that wyth in it lyghtelly as much maye be founde by it, as by a great concordaunce: I ceaÅ¿Å¿ed not tyll I had it tranÅ¿lated and Å¿ett in lyke order in the EnglyÅ¿h tounge, that your grace myghte not be deÅ¿tytute of Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿arye an inÅ¿trumente in your godlye Å¿tudie. And that all other whych be Å¿tudyouÅ¿e of godly knowledge myghte be the more deÅ¿yrouÅ¿e to haue thys lyttle boke and embrace it wyth better wyll (knowynge your graces feruent zeale in the furtherynge of goddis trueth.) I haue (byn as my duitie byndeth me Å¿o boulde as to) dedycated vnto your grace for to forther youre grace in youre godly Å¿tudye, truÅ¿tinge that your grace according to your a cuÅ¿tomable gentilnes will accept my good wyll there in, and then Å¿hall I thynke my laboures
well employed & my Paynes well recompenÅ¿ed.

Nowe leÅ¿te your grace Å¿houlde be diÅ¿ceyued in any thynge conteyned in this lytle boke: Yt may pleace your grace to vnderÅ¿tande that the PÅ¿almes from the nynth PÅ¿alme forwarde, are euer one fewer in nomber then the Å¿ame PÅ¿almes be in the Bybels which be tranÅ¿lated and prynted into EnglyÅ¿he. As for enÅ¿ample, that PÅ¿alm which in this boke is noted .x. is in the Bibles .xi. and Å¿o forth to the ende of the PÅ¿almes, accordynge to the counte of the Grekes.

It behoueth alÅ¿o, that your grace be admonyÅ¿hed of thys one other thynge, whych other wyÅ¿e myght hapely be a great trouble to your grace in the Å¿ekeynge of matthers whych ye Å¿hall deÅ¿yre to fynde. The letters A. B. C. D. E. F. G. Whych be commonly Å¿et in the margyne of euerye chappter of the Byble, to deuide the chapter into Å¿o many partis: Are not Å¿et in all Bybles a lyke. So that the thynge that in one boke Å¿taÌ deth vpon ,B, or ,C. doeth in an other boke, Å¿tande vpon .D. or .E. And thys dyuerÅ¿ytye is growen by the negligence ã2 pages missingã
â¢â¦ caÅ¿yon of many dowbts.

And as tochyng all other thinges neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be knowen abowt thys boke. I deÅ¿yre your grace to take the payn to rede ouer the preface followyng: which the great lernyd men that were the firÅ¿t authors of the boke dyd Å¿ett before yt vnto the vnderÅ¿tandynge of the Redar.

Nowe to Å¿peake Å¿ome thynge of the commoditie and profite that Å¿pryngeth of thys boke: I do your grace to vnderÅ¿tande that from the fyrÅ¿te begynnynge of learnynge, all learned men haue thought it Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿erie a thynge to the forderaunce of theyr Å¿tudie, that yf they coulde by no mean â¢ s haue the lyke that were Å¿ome what to theyr mynde: they woulde not Å¿tycke to take the paynes to drawe oute one for theyr owne Å¿tudye, (and Å¿o dyd the fyrÅ¿t Authours of thys boke,) whyche doubtleÅ¿Å¿e they would neuer haue done yf neceÅ¿Å¿itye of the thynge had not dryuen them to it. MooÅ¿te neceÅ¿Å¿arye therfore it is for all maner of perÅ¿ons (that do employe any parte of theyr Å¿tudy to the holy Å¿criptures) to haue eyther thys or the lyke table or concordaunce to helpe theyr memorye
wyth all. PurpoÅ¿ly therefore to profite all maner of perÅ¿ons I haue Å¿et forth thys lyttle worcke, commytting it to your gracys tuyÅ¿yon, wyÅ¿hynge that all men myght be profited thereby and no mann offended. The Å¿piryte of the lyueyng God be all wayes your gracys comforther and guide in all your doingis to the glory of God and your Å¿owls health. So be it.

closer.signed: Your Graeces humble and bounden dayly Orator. Gwalter Lynne

div.head: Henry Bullynger, Leo Iude, Conrade Pellicane, and the other miniÅ¿ters of the churche of Tygurie. Sende vnto the ChriÅ¿tian reader gretynge.
div.p:
Dearely beloued brethren in ChriÅ¿te IeÅ¿u, to thintent that euery man may Å¿o much the fru â¢ fuller vÅ¿e and occupye this regiÅ¿ter or table it is to be noted for an introduccion and good vnderÅ¿tanding, that it Å¿erueth principally for three maner of poinctes FirÅ¿t it Å¿heweth the hiÅ¿tories of the olde and newe TeÅ¿tament, whiche are Å¿oone founde, hauinge a reÅ¿pect and regarde to the proper names whiche in the hiÅ¿tories and actes, which are Å¿ought for, chefelye do occurre. As if thou deÅ¿ireÅ¿t to knowe, where and in what place of the Å¿cripture is written ye hyÅ¿tory of innocent Abell, of the righteous Abraham, and of the obedient
IÅ¿aac, or of the feruent Helias, then Å¿e
â¢â¦ the Å¿ame name euery one by his lettre, and when thou haÅ¿t founde hym, thou Å¿halt fynde there a trewe introduction to the forÅ¿ayde hiÅ¿torie, howe be it there is to be noted, that the proper names are not euery where wrytten after one Å¿ort, but that they haue Å¿ome difference, for Å¿ome of them are written in Å¿ome places with an .H. and in Å¿ome places without an .H. as Habel or Abel, Elias or Helias Ebron or Hebron, Iericho or Hiericho, And Å¿ome are in one place written with a .C. as Cain, Cades, Caath, and in an other place with a .K. as Kain, Kades, Caath. Some alÅ¿o are written in one place with an .S. as Sacharias, Sidekia, Sidon, Sorobabell, & in an other place with an .Z. as Zacharias, Zidechias, Zidon Zorobabel. Therfore gentill reader if any of Å¿uche lyke wordes in the Å¿earchyng out of any hiÅ¿tory do occure, and thy mynde be not Å¿atiÅ¿fyed in one place, or lettre, let it not be tedious vnto the, to reÅ¿ort to the other lettre, as it is afore mencioned.

Secondely dothe this RegiÅ¿ter alÅ¿o Å¿hewe almooÅ¿t euery perÅ¿ones, certayn
Å¿ayenges and places, whereof it maye be gathered, what there dominion office and honoure and deutie or behaueoure is, what Å¿he alÅ¿o ineÅ¿peciall ought to endeuoure her Å¿elfe to do and to leaue vndone towardes them, with whome Å¿he hath ought to do becauÅ¿e of her office or of her eÅ¿tate. BeÅ¿ydes this certain examples of Å¿uche as haue behaued theÌ Å¿elues well or euell, in Å¿uche theyr offices, as namely, what they ought, and are bounde to do to there Å¿ubiectes, how the ByÅ¿hoppes ought to behaue them Å¿elues towardes the churche. Fathers and mothers towardes their chyldren, and howe yuell or well Å¿ome haue ordred them Å¿elues, in the premyÅ¿Å¿es.

Thyrdely, this regiÅ¿ter leadeth alÅ¿o to the Å¿entences and places, which may be conducyble & profytable for the trew vnderÅ¿tandynge and learnynge of the chiefe articles and moÅ¿t common pointes of the holy Å¿cripture (of the whiche euery faythfull ChriÅ¿tian for his confeÅ¿Å¿ions and ChriÅ¿ten names Å¿ake ought to haue Å¿ome knowledge and vnderÅ¿tandyng) as what is to be knowen by theÅ¿e wordes God, ChriÅ¿t, men, lawe,
Å¿ynne, &c. And all theÅ¿e thynges haue we â¢â¦ eyned in Å¿uche wyÅ¿e, that thou arte not only brought and ledde to the chapiter, but alÅ¿o to the letters, whiche are Å¿et ought beÅ¿ydes euery chapiter in the margent, to thintent that by the meanes thereof, thou myghteÅ¿t be eaÅ¿ed of much labour and Å¿houldeÅ¿t not nede for one pointe onely to rede ouer the whole chapiters from the begynnyng to the place whiche thou haÅ¿te taken in hande, and where as Å¿ometyme the whole chapiter from the begynnyng, or els from a letter, out to thende, intreateth of one matter and Å¿erueth to one purpoÅ¿e, there haue we, for to eÅ¿chue prolixitie lefte out the letters of the Å¿ame in Å¿tede whereof we haue put and ordeined a * wherby is Å¿ygnified that the Å¿ame chapiter intreateth of the Å¿ame matter out to the ende, and thus we commende you to GOD.

div.head: Gwalter Lynne to the Reader.
div.p: GEntill Reader yf that you woll take the paynes, as to reade ouer the EpyÅ¿tell dedycated to me Lady of SomerÅ¿etts grace, and the Preface of the Authoures before named, there by Å¿hall you comme to the ryghte knoweledge and vÅ¿e of the readynge of thys brefe Concordaunce, God geue vs grace that we maye Å¿o reade and vÅ¿e it to the honoure of hys name and to the profyte of our bretheren and neyghboures and oure Å¿aluacion. Amen.

Dearely beloued bretheren and fryendes I praye you hartely make you well aquaynted wyth the bokes of the holy Bybell thorouwe muche readynge of them Å¿o Å¿hall you be much EaÅ¿ed in Å¿ekynge any thynge aboue named in the Prefaces. ij. Timo iij.c.For all Å¿crypture geuen by inÅ¿pyracyon of God is profytable to teache, to ymproue, to amende, and to inÅ¿turct in ryghteouÅ¿nes, that the man of God maye be perfect and prepared vnto
all good workes.
ij. Petr. i.d.For the Å¿cripture came neuer by the wyll of man: But holye men of God Å¿pake as they were moued by the holy gooÅ¿t.
Zachar. vij.c.Whyche the Lorde of hooÅ¿tes Å¿ente in hys holy Å¿pyryte by the prophetes afore tyme.

argument.head: The content of this boke.
argument.p:
HEre in is declared the fearfull punyÅ¿hemente of the BlaÅ¿phemous tyranny of Ptolomeus. Item what myÅ¿chefe he dyd afterwardes enterpryÅ¿e againÅ¿te the Iewes, whiche God neuertheles dyd gracyouÅ¿ly wythÅ¿tand and brought it to a good ende, therby Å¿ygnyfyeng vnto vs, that
the hartes of Kinges and Princes and of all men are in hys hande. Prouerb. xxi.a. iiij. Regum. i.c.d. ij. HeÅ¿ter. vi.b. And that noman Å¿hallbe confounded that putteth hys thruÅ¿t and confidence in hym. EÅ¿aye. xlix.e. xxviij.c. lvii.b. PÅ¿al. xxv.a. xxxi.a. xxxvij c. lxxi.a. Roman. ix.d. v.a. &c.

chapter 1
Zurich part A Dan. xi b. WHen Philopater had vnderÅ¿tande by thoos that were comen agayne that Antiochus had taken froÌ hym Å¿uche holdes as he had, he rayÅ¿ed all hys army aÅ¿well fote men as horÅ¿emen, and taking with him his Å¿iÅ¿ter ArÅ¿inoe, he ranne out euen affare as the countries of Raphia, that were borderynge vpon hym, where Antiochus hoÅ¿t camped. And one Theodotus, thynkynge to brynge the matter to paÅ¿Å¿e by craftye traines, when he hadde taken the Å¿trongeÅ¿t men of armys, that were put vnto hym by Ptolomeus, in the night he gat him to Ptolomeus tent to kyll hym vnwares, and Å¿o make an end of the battel. But DoÅ¿itheus called the Å¿onne of Drimilius a Iewe borne, and afterwardes forÅ¿akyng the Lawe,
and tourned from hys fathers ordinauÌ ces, whiche was hired for the purpoÅ¿e, put in hys Å¿teede in the tente an other poore man, which chaunÅ¿ed to be Å¿layn for him. And as they fought fearcely together. But Antiochus moare. ArÅ¿inoe went diligently about her men, wering pitifully, her heare about her Å¿huldars, and deÅ¿yred them, that they would healpe her valiauntly, promiÅ¿inge to gy â¢â¦ vnto euery of there wiues and children, yf the had the vyctory two poundes of golde. Thys is chaunÅ¿ed that there enemies were ouer thrownen, and many taken. Then whan he hadde thus dyÅ¿apointed there traines, he went about ye cities that were next, and thought to coÌ fort them wyth wordes, whiche when he had done, he gaue 3. Macha. h. gyftes vnto ther churches, and conforted the Å¿ubiectes hartes. part B And when the Iewes had Å¿ent the elders of there counÅ¿ailours to Philopater to Å¿alute hym, berynge gyftes and to Å¿hewe there, for the thyngs that he hadde done, it fortuned that he hadd a greater deÅ¿yre to go to theym aÅ¿Å¿one as might be. So he came to IeruÅ¿alem and dyd Å¿acrifice to the moÅ¿te myghtye God, and wheÌ he had done, he dyd to ye
place as was conuenient. Mathe. xxiiij.a. Luk. xxi a. Mar. xii a. And after when he was come in, he wondred to Å¿ee the coÅ¿tly worcke, and meruelynge at the fine buyldynge of the temple, he deÅ¿yred to go alÅ¿o into the innar tabernacle that was holieÅ¿t of all. But when they denyed hym Å¿ayenge it was not leafull, no not to eny that were borne there, to go in, not Å¿o much as for ye prieÅ¿tes them Å¿elues Å¿aue only for the cheaffe byÅ¿hopExo. xxx b. Leui. xvi g. Heb. ix.a, & that but onÅ¿e in the yere onlye, yet woulde he not betourned one wyth. And when they reade vnto him ye law, yet would he not ceaÅ¿e, but Å¿aid he mult nedes go in. And al though this honor was denied vnto theÌ, yet ye it ought not to be Å¿o vnto him, & axed theÌ, why no maÌ yet Å¿topped him froÌ going in to eny teÌples. And wheÌ one had made anÅ¿were vnaduiÅ¿edlye, yt they did well becauÅ¿e they did not, but this quoth he, Å¿hall be done & let the cauÅ¿e what Å¿o eny the lyÅ¿t, he would in whither they would or not. part C
Zurich part B ij. Mach iij.c. And when the pryeÅ¿tes hadde fallen wt there faces vpoÌ the ground and were in all there veÅ¿timentes, and prayed vnto the higheÅ¿t god, to helpe them in there moÅ¿te nede, and that he woulde put
awaye his Å¿trenght that threatened to hurt them, & had filled the temple with cryeng and weapinge, the reÅ¿t that were in the cytye beyng greatly amaÅ¿ed, & not knowyng what hadde happened, came out as faÅ¿t as they could. Virgens that were in the chaumbers, & women in child bed ran forth, caÅ¿ting duÅ¿t vpon there heddes and filling the Å¿treat with morning and lamentacion. And the banners that they had a lytle before prepared to go meat hym, forgettynge the maner that be came them, they bare them about the cytye and forÅ¿akynge ye young infantes, bothe mothers & merÅ¿es ran wanderinge about the Å¿treates, Å¿ome one waye, Å¿ome another into the hyghe temple, and beynge gathered together, Å¿triued diuerÅ¿ly agaynÅ¿te thoÅ¿e thynges whyche he wyckedly wente aboute. part D BeÅ¿ides this the cityzens moued wyth bouldnes, woulde not Å¿uffer hym to ruÅ¿he in, and accompleÅ¿h hys purpoÅ¿e but toke them to there weapons, and wyth great cryes redy to Å¿uffer death, they Å¿tyrred vp a great buÅ¿ynes in that place, but yet remoued back by the prieÅ¿tes and Å¿eniores, they came agayne to

earth, part B ij Par vi a. &. vij.c haÅ¿t choÅ¿eÌ this city, and haÅ¿t halowed thys place to honor the in all though that thou haÅ¿t nede of nothing, and haÅ¿te made it goodly to be Å¿ene to thyne owne prayÅ¿e & glory of thy great and riall name. For the loue alÅ¿o of the houÅ¿e of IÅ¿raell thou haÅ¿te promyÅ¿ed that when we haue arred, wherby troubles Å¿houlde come vpon vs yf we come in to thys place to praie that thou wilt heare our praiers. And verely thou art faythfull and full of trouth. And by cauÅ¿e thou haÅ¿t often holpen our forfathers, Read Iudicum ye whole boke ouer wheÌ they haue byne oppreÅ¿Å¿ed wyth trouble. And haÅ¿t delyuered them out of great perels, & now alÅ¿o beholde (O holy kinge) that we for our many & great Å¿innes be preÅ¿Å¿ed and in our enemies Å¿ubiectioÌ, faule doune in or miÅ¿ery for lack of Å¿trenght, and that thys Å¿touberne and vnclene perÅ¿on goeth aboute to defyle thy holy place, whych is dedicat here in the earth to thy holy name (for other wyÅ¿e thy houÅ¿e is in heauen a place yt nomaÌ can come vnto) I Å¿aye bethou cauÅ¿e of thyne awne good wyll yt haÅ¿t gyuen thys glory to thy people in dedicatynge thys place vnto the, laye
not to our charg ye vnclenlineÅ¿Å¿e of thees men nor correct vs for the vnhalowing of yt thees wicked perÅ¿ons may not boÅ¿t in there mindes and a vaunce with there tounges that they haue deÅ¿troied our holy teÌple, as they do treade vnder foot all other temples that thou hateÅ¿t, put out our Å¿innes & Å¿trypke awaie our fawtes and nowe Å¿hewe thy mercye. Lett vs haue thy mercye Å¿hortelye and make the monthes of them that be fallen and broken prayÅ¿e the and geue vs peace. Then he that Å¿eeth all thynges, and God of al the moÅ¿t holieÅ¿t, hearing there lawful prayer driuynge hym hether and thether, whyche was puffed vp by vyolence and great Å¿toubernes, euen as the wynd doth the read, dyd Å¿o Å¿courge hym, that now he laie vpon the ground meate for nothynge loÅ¿ed in all the partes of the body and iuÅ¿tly wrapped in punyÅ¿hemente was not able to Å¿peake one worde. And thoÅ¿e wordes Å¿pake he and they incontinent being loÅ¿ed when they had eÅ¿caped death, prayÅ¿ed the holy God their Å¿auiour. part E Then afterwardes the kyng commyng agayne into the citie, he called vnto hym his Å¿tewarde, & commaunded wine and other thynges, that partayne to a feaÅ¿te to be geuen vnto them by the Å¿pace of Å¿euen dayes, and

chapter 7
part A
Zurich part X THe kynge Ptolomie Philopater, to all hys rulers that be thourough Egipte, and all that beare eny offyce, Å¿endyth greatynge and health for we and oure children be in health. After that the greate
God had Å¿ent vs good Å¿peede euen we our Å¿elfe would wyÅ¿h Å¿ome of our frendes thorow there waywardnes made often inÅ¿tant labour vnto vs, and perÅ¿uaded vs to call to gether the Iewes that were vnder our Å¿ubiection & cruelly to punyÅ¿he them as traytours, for they Å¿ayde we Å¿hould neuer be in quiet, becauÅ¿e of the hate that they bare againÅ¿t all men tyll we had Å¿o done. And after that they had Å¿ore vexed them and brought them hether bounde as Å¿laues or rather as theues and murtherers, with out all enquirye oure pledynge of the cauÅ¿e, they woulde haue kylled them more cruell then the Scythyans. But we rebukyng them Å¿harply for it, according to our gentylnes toward all men, and after we had much worcke to Å¿aue them a lyue by oure fauoure, and when we knewe for a Å¿uretye that the heauenlye God defendid the Iewes, and that in euery poynt he holpe them, as the father hys chyldren, part B and that alÅ¿o we dyd conÅ¿ider the good wil which they bere vnto vs, as they haue to oure auncitours, we haue iuÅ¿tly quyte them from all fautes what Å¿o euer was laide
agaynÅ¿t them and haue commaunded euerye man in euerye place that they Å¿houlde be Å¿uffred to go to there owne, and that no man Å¿houlde hurt them, or caÅ¿t them in the teath wyth any thynge that they haue Å¿uffered, for ye Å¿hall vnderÅ¿tand, that yf we iiij Reg xix.d. Iere xxx c. ij a. x d Zac ij.b Mathe. xxv.d. Act. ix.a haue done eny hurt, agayeÅ¿te them malycyouÅ¿lye or by any meanes haue made them Å¿adde, that we Å¿hall haue agaynÅ¿te vs, not a man but the hye God rular of all powre to be reuenged of thees deedes in euery point alwayes and neuer hable tobe auoydyd. Fare ye well. Zurich part Y Yet when they had receyued thys epyÅ¿tell, they made not haÅ¿t Å¿traight waies to go there wayes, but they deÅ¿yred this thynge alÅ¿o of the kynge, that whoÅ¿oeuer of the Iewes nacion had violatet ye holy God or willingly iij. Ma f. broken hys lawes, that they myghte be punyÅ¿hed of them as they hadde deÅ¿eruyd, Å¿ayeng, part C â that they whyche had tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ed goddes lawe for there bellye Å¿ake, woulde neuer be faythfull to the kynges commaundement. He thyncking them to Å¿ay trewe, prayÅ¿ed them and gaue them powre to kyll thorowe all hys kyngdome thoÅ¿e
that had broke the lawe of God, and that they Å¿huolde not Å¿eke for eny powre of the kynge. Then they as reaÅ¿on was, thanckinge the kynge, the prieÅ¿tes and all the people wyth them cryeng. Alleluya, went away wyth ioy, and as thei went killed euery one of the nacion that was naught for example to other and in dede that daye, they killed aboue thre hundreth men, and were verie ioyyuos as they kylled them. But thoos that Å¿tacke to God to death, hauing the ful fruet of there health, they went out of the cytye crowned wyth verye Å¿wete flowers of all Å¿ortes wyth cryeng and gladnes, giuing praiÅ¿e to the holy God of there fathers ye Å¿auiour of IÅ¿rael. part D
Zurich part Z And when they were come to Ptolomeus. Rodophoros, Å¿o called after the nature of the place where a nauye taryed for them, they kepte a feaÅ¿te there by there hole conÅ¿entes. vij. dayes, the kyng geuyng vnto them gladly all thynges neceÅ¿Å¿ary to there iouruey, tyll they came home. So departyng Å¿afe with worthy gratulacions, ther alÅ¿o they purpoÅ¿ed to kepe thoÅ¿e glad dayes for the tyme of, there being in a Å¿trannge lawe, and makyng
and dedicating a pillar of prayer in the place where they feaÅ¿ted, they went their waye Å¿afe both by lande and by Å¿ea fre and mery. And euery man came home to his houÅ¿e by the kynges coÌ maundement, hauyng greater power againÅ¿t the enemies with glory and feare, then euer they had before, nor they were not let from there goodes by any man, for all men receiued there goodes as they were named in the byll of attendure, Å¿o that whoÅ¿oeuer had any thyng of theers, reÅ¿tored it agayne, with great feare, the hye God finiÅ¿hyng the matters, to all there healthes. PraiÅ¿ed be God the delyuerer of IÅ¿rael worlde without ende. Amen.
